newsitem.title: CANADA: De Havilland workers ratify new three-year deal.
newsitem.headline: De Havilland workers ratify new three-year deal.

text.p: Unionized workers at Bombardier Inc's de Havilland unit voted 83 percent in favor of ratifying a new three-year deal on Saturday, narrowly averting a strike.

The agreement, which covers 3,400 production and office workers at de Havilland's Downsview, Ontario, plant provides for average wage increases of 2.3 percent each year including cost of living allowances.
The average plant worker now earns about C$21 ($15) an hour.
"This is a really good agreement," said Merv Gray, plant chairman with the Canadian Auto Workers Local 112. "We got those across-the-board wage increases which were very important."
Gray said the only disappointment was over the size of pension benefits. Workers will receive pension gains of about 10 percent over the life of the agreement.
The union also said it won better protection from outside contracting.
A tentative agreement reached on Monday was endorsed unanimously by the union's bargaining committee.
The Downsview plant makes the de Havilland Dash-8 family of turboprop regional aircraft and is responsible for the final assembly of the new Bombardier Global Express long-range business jet.
Montreal-based Bombardier acquired control of the company from Boeing Co in 1994.
